Postop Phaco.description: Post-op Phaco medications include antibiotics - prophylaxis for infection, anti-inflammatories for surgical uveitis, tropicamide, and artificial tears.

drug.clientInfo: This medication is a topical antibiotic.
drug.blurb:
* Similar to NeoPolyBac but is a __solution__ :sweat_drops: instead of an ointment 
* Used for prophylaxis or nonspecific surface infection. Not indicated as empirical therapy for deep/stromal ulcers 
* Broad spectrum but poor penetration 
* Dose for prophylaxis is typically BID 
* :cat: There is a [report](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21906985) of suspected anaphylaxis with use of topical antibiotics (e.g. TAB or terramycin) in cats. The chance of a reaction is likely extremely remote but no data is available as to how remote

drug.clientInfo: This medication is a topical steroid and is contraindicated with corneal ulcers. Stop and call if squinting is noted.
drug.blurb:
* Indicated for control of active anterior segment inflammation (i.e. uveitis) 
* Good penetration through intact epithelium (better than dexamethasone) 
* Dose depends on degree of inflammation (QID+ if severe, q24h-TID if less)

drug.clientInfo: This medication is a topical non-steroidal anti-inflammatory (NSAID).
drug.blurb:
* Topical NSAID 
* Usually insufficient alone for treatment of uveitis 
* Concurrent use in cases of corneal ulceration is questionable out of concern for impairment of epithelial healing and reports of melting secondary to NSAID use in veterinary and people 
* :+1: Comes in a 10 mL bottle

drug.clientInfo: This medication is to help dilate the pupil.
drug.blurb:
* Used primarily for short-acting mydriasis - quick acting (15-30 min effect) with limited duration of effect (few hours depending on species) 
* Limited cycloplegia so not as useful as atropine for ciliary body spasm

drug.clientInfo: This is a topical artificial tear gel.
drug.blurb: * Provides prolonged lubrication vs eye drops
